title: Investigative task - close shaves by razor brand

content.question: Directions: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A consumer group compared the longevity of two types of razor blades: an inexpensive generic blade and a more expensive name-brand blade. Two independent samples were randomly selected—one consisted of ten generic blades and the other consisted of ten name-brand blades. The number of shaves obtained before a blade became too dull to provide a close shave was recorded for each blade in the two independent samples. Create a back-to-back stemplot to display the distributions of the data. In a few sentences, compare the distributions in part (a). To test whether the name-brand blades tend to last longer than the generic blades on average, a two-sample t-test was performed. The conditions for inference were checked and verified. The test statistic was t=0.87 with a p-value of 0.20. What should be concluded about whether the name-brand blades last significantly longer than the generic blades? Explain. Also of interest to the consumer group is whether the generic (G) blades have more variability in the number of close shaves than the name-brand (B) blades. The consumer group intends to use the ratio of the sample standard deviations <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>s</mi> <mi>G</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>s</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C56@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, as a test statistic to test the hypothesis <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>H</mi> <mn>0</mn> </msub> <mtext> </mtext> <mo>:</mo> <mtext> </mtext> <msub> <mi>σ</mi> <mi>G</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>σ</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42F3@</annotation> </semantics> </math> verses <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>H</mi> <mi>a</mi> </msub> <mtext> </mtext> <mo>:</mo> <mtext> </mtext> <msub> <mi>σ</mi> <mi>G</mi> </msub> <mo>></mo> <msub> <mi>σ</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4321@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. The group conducted a simulation study to investigate the sampling distribution of the test statistic when the population standard deviations were actually the same. For each repetition of the simulation, two independent samples of size 10 were selected from the same normally distributed population, and the ratio of their sample standard deviations was computed. Explain why the median of the distribution of a sample of 1,000 of these simulated ratios will be about 1. A histogram for the 1,000 simulated values of the ratio <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>s</mi> <mi>G</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>s</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C56@</annotation> </semantics> </math> is shown below. Summary statistics for the original data (number of close shaves) are provided in the table below. Is there convincing evidence that the generic blades have more variability in the number of close shaves than the name-brand blades? Explain.

topic.text: 1.5: Representing a Quantitative Variable with Graphs

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct numerical or graphical representations of distributions.
